{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3341008,"name":"Gavin Kistner","username":"Phrogz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/phrogz/{size}/217285_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T23:11:57.541Z","cooked":"

Our team has odometry self-tracking our swerve location. The team believes it’s pretty good. But we know it will drift, or jump with the wrong collisions.

So we added AprilTag detection, hoping it would simply give us perfect localization. Suprise (to no-one here): it is imperfect. Noisy, unreliable. So, we want to fuse our self-tracking with AprilTags, in the “right” way. People say Kalman filters are the right way, and they’re probably right. But they’re also hard.

So, instead of putting in the hard work to fully grok non-linear fused Kalman filters, I thought I’d see if simple IIR fusion could work well enough. Result: I think it does.

To test it, I wrote a REALLY rough simulation. The bot can see one or more AprilTags using roughly-correct real-world values. They produce really bad poses for the robot, which get worse and more flickery the farther away the robot is (or the farther off-axis the tag is from the camera’s center). The bot occasionally gets bumped (which totally throws off our internal odometry) and I also made the simulated odometry far worse than our real one (through some bug I’ve not even found :p).

The README here describes how it works. (Summary: IIR filter that smooths the estimate heavily towards the odometry prediction, and then lightly towards any AprilTag detections.)

Want to drive the robot yourself? Have you/your students play around with JavaScript code? Be my guest! The whole simulation is just a few hundred lines of JavaScript and HTML, including all visualization. The core algorithm is just 6 lines of JS.

Have you tried benchmarking your algorithm vs WPILib’s Pose Estimators?

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Pose Estimators

WPILib includes pose estimators for differential, swerve and mecanum drivetrains. These estimators are designed to be drop-in replacements for the existing odometry classes that also support fusing...

Phrogz:

I thought I’d see if simple IIR fusion could work well enough

FYI, WPILib’s pose estimators use a linear Kalman filter, which is just a single-pole IIR filter on x, y, and heading (derivation, source).

Single-pole IIR filters poorly model the true probability distribution though. There are other ways.

gtsam

604 went down this path for about a week, didn’t ever try it out on a real robot, and decided that particle filters were easier to teach to HS students. We might revisit factor graphs again one day…

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":27,"updated_at":"2024-03-23T06:15:37.291Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":442,"readers_count":441,"score":213.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459755,"topic_slug":"odometry-fusion-simpler-than-kalman","display_username":"Eugene Fang","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":"The-Blue-Alliance","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/0/2/02b18ea7720fea44e77469bb5261acf1c7045a6e.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":67,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P11X8S9Vn9I","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":6},{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NOO_pLSVpb4","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53190,"username":"truher","name":"joel truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7439,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"604 Alum & Mentor | The Blue Alliance"},"post_url":"/t/odometry-fusion-simpler-than-kalman/459755/9","custom_user_title":"604 Alum & Mentor | The Blue Alliance","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3341215,"name":"Jared Russell","username":"Jared_Russell","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jared_russell/{size}/399_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-23T06:43:23.472Z","cooked":"

A factor graph would be great, but I think before doing that it would make sense to fix a bigger issue with the WPIlib pose estimators: treating odometry as a direct predictor of pose rather than a differential measurement that gets integrated to obtain pose.

Right now if you drive around without a vision update for a lot of time / distance, your state variance never grows. But that’s not how odometry actually works (if it was, we wouldn’t need vision!). Instead, we should expect uncertainty to grow roughly quadratically with time/distance absent vision updates (and therefore, a vision update after not seeing a target for a period of time should have a more rapid effect on resetting the state estimate than during periods where we’re getting frequent vision updates and the odometric pose estimate hasn’t had much time to accumulate drift).

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":27,"updated_at":"2024-03-23T06:44:26.504Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":414,"readers_count":413,"score":412.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459755,"topic_slug":"odometry-fusion-simpler-than-kalman","display_username":"Jared Russell","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/kalman-filter-question/477269/4","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Kalman Filter Question","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16846,"username":"calcmogul","name":"Tyler Veness","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":17}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1267,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Oh so close"},"post_url":"/t/odometry-fusion-simpler-than-kalman/459755/10","custom_user_title":"Oh so close","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":17}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":17,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3341218,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-23T07:05:50.383Z","cooked":"

You’re correct, and that’s how the pose estimators used to work. It used a square-root UKF and KalmanFilterLatencyCompensator to update prior error covariances, by replaying encoder and gyro measurements, in response to delayed CV pose measurements. It ended up being way too CPU-intensive for the roboRIO (even in C++) and numerically unstable, so we replaced it with what the pose estimators do now.

When we get a robot controller that isn’t a potato in 2027, we should be able to do better. Particle filters are likely too expensive for the roboRIO, because it’s basically the same thing as a sigma point filter (the UKF we already tried), but with even more state vector samples. Also, I’m told factor graphs are similarly expensive because it’s solving a similar problem to the UKF, but in iterative rather than closed form.

Until the robot controller is replaced, we may just have to recommend people use our raspberry pi library builds to get the speed they need for more CPU-intensive features.

Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-23T07:48:33.997Z","cooked":"

Oh yeah, I noticed that when reading through the pose estimation code that odometry updates are replayed linearly.

In my experience, odometry is usually represented as its own self contained reference frame, and sensor correction is just a single transform.

So to get the current pose it’s just Odom(t) + offset, and to update with a vision estimate it’s new_offset = measurement(t) - (odom(t) + offset)

This assumes that pose deltas are independent of the actual pose which I think is true is it not? Maybe I’m missing something specific to swerve odometry.

I can’t speak for the other team. but the keys are low (<2ms) exposure, a stable mount, and generally higher FPS/lower latency.

How does fps and latency change things? If I have captured a clear image I will detect the april tag in it, but thank you I’ll check how high is the exposure and if the mount is moving or not, our cameras are mounted on our swerve protectors

High FPS and low latency means your results are as up-to-date as possible, which makes things easier for all the pose estimation filters and whatnot as the data is recent, of special importance when you’re moving fast.

That works for one odometry pose sample in the pose buffer, but if you don’t also update odometry pose samples after the CV measurement (remember, the CV pose gets matched with an old odometry pose), future CV corrections will be using pose estimates that are no longer valid (i.e., they don’t account for the new information from CV).

A similar thing occurs for in a UKF, because the error covariance has to be updated at every timestep, and that changes the contribution amounts of future measurements.

Nope. My concern was not execution speed (though the IIR is about as little computation as I can imagine), but rather simplicity. Simple to understand, simple to implement, simple to tweak. Our programmers can play with Kalman filters over the summer, but I’m afraid tackling them mid-season will be days spent trying to understand and implement when that could be spent on improving our auto.

I should note that we’ve seen some preliminary results indicating movement speed will be an issue for our detections. I did not model that in the simulation. Thanks for pointing it out; to make my (already terrible) simulation slightly more realistic, I should make the likelihood of dropping a detection increase based on velocity.

calcmogul:

(remember, the CV pose gets matched with an old odometry pose

Sorry, I should have specified that t is allowed to be different in those equations.

Lets say you have a sequence of odometry poses [p0, p1, p2, p3], and you get a vision measurement q1 which matches with p1, and I fuse q1 with p1 to produce p1'. To compute p3', you “replay” the odometry in p2 and p3. I’m arguing that p3' - p1' == p3 - p1, or that the relative transform between p1 and p3 is unchanged by our q1 measurement. With a simple manipulation, you can show that p3' == (p3 - p1) + p1' == p3 + (p1' - p1). The offset I mentioned earlier is the (p1' - p1). When you get a new measurement, q2, you use p2' to compute p2'', and a new offset p2'' - p2 to be added to future odometry readings.

This is how I’ve done this sort of thing in the past. The key assumption is that the absolute position of the robot doesn’t impact the relative transforms in odometry. Maybe this assumption is wrong for swerve? I’d be curious how.

As for the error covariance with a UKF, I would agree that complicates things. The order of operations for those matrix updates is definitely relevant, but in practice it might just be “good enough” to apply those to most recent covariance. In this case I’m just BSing though, that part could just be totally wrong.
